debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 21 November 1979:

item.para: Has the Attorney-General 's attention been drawn to the relationship which exists between the Housing Institute of Australia and the Institute of Arbitrators, Australia.
If so, is the legal officer of the Housing Institute of Australia also the President of the Institute of Arbitrators, Australia.
Does the President of the Institute of Arbitrators,

question.para: Australia, appoint arbitrators to hear building disputes against members of the builders trade union, the Housing Institute of Australia.

item.para: Does the Housing Institute of Australia produce a building contract that has a'Scott/Avery' single arbitration clause whereby disputees are forced to arbitration without prior recourse to the courts or the Small Claims Tribunal.

Can the Attorney-General say whether the New South Wales Law Reform Commission in its report on Commercial Arbitration has condemned 'Scott/Avery' clauses and recommended that they be made void as per the Victorian Instruments Act, 1 958, concerning insurance contracts.
Was this recommendation supported by the Law Reform Commission of the Australian Capital Territory.
Does the new model building contract of the Housing Institute of Australia, published in January 1979, compel owners to accept the builders nominee as arbitrator.

Can the Attorney-General say whether the majority of arbitrators of the Institute of Arbitrators, Australia, are either past or present officials of the Housing Institute of Australia or the Master Builders Association.
Can the Attorney-General also say whether the Institute of Arbitrators, Australia, was formed under the auspices of the Royal Institute of Architects and the Master Builders Federation of Australia.

Have the building contracts of the Housing Institute of Australia, the Master Builders Association and the Commonwealth Savings Bank been examined to see if they are in conflict with item (0 of the Trade Practices Commission Information Circular No. 22.

Is the Attorney-General prepared to consider the possibility of a conflict of interests under the Housing Institute of Australia contract and the appointment of arbitrators by the Institute of Arbitrators, Australia.
Has the Attorney-General received any complaints concerning unjust arbitration awards; if so, how many complaints have been received, what was their nature and what was the outcome.

Has the Attorney-General's attention been drawn to a statement by a former Attorney-General who, on 30 June 1 976, stated that he was in the process of causing an ordinance to be prepared for the Australian Capital Territory, to give effect, broadly, to the ACT Law Reform Commission's recommendation contained in its report on the law relating to commercial arbitration; if so, does the Attorney-General intend to honour this undertaking.

talk.start.para: - The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

item.para: to (4) These are not matters falling within my ministerial responsibility.

The New South Wales Law Reform Commission's report on Commercial Arbitration dated October 1976 recommended that legislation be enacted to avoid a contractual stipulation whereby an award or other step in an arbitration is a condition of a cause of action or a defence in legal proceedings.

The Report on the Law Relating to Commercial Arbitration was issued by the Australian Capital Territory Law Reform Commission on 1 1 August 1974. In relation to the Scott/Avery clause the recommendation was:

answer.para: A provision (whether in an agreement to arbitrate or otherwise) than an award under an agreement to arbitrate shall be a condition precedent to the bringing of an action with respect to any matter to which such agreement applies, shall be read only as an agreement to arbitrate and shall not prevent any cause of action from accruing before arbitration and shall not affect the institution, prosecution or defence of any action or counterclaim.'

item.para: to (1 1) These are not matters falling within my ministerial responsibility.

There is no record within the Attorney-General's Department of any complaints concerning unjust arbitration awards having been received since the presentation of the Australian Capital Territory Law Reform Commission report on commercial arbitration.

1 3) I am aware of my predecessor's statement. A first draft of an ACT Arbitration Ordinance was prepared by late 1976. In October 1976 the NSW Law Reform Commission Report on Commercial Arbitration became available and the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General agreed to a study of that and other reports with a view to the enactment of uniform commercial arbitration legislation. In view of that development further progress on an ACT Ordinance was deferred. The Standing Committee has agreed on the principles for uniform legislation which, inter alia, excludes the use of Scott v. Avery type clauses. Drafting of a model uniform Bill giving effect to those principles is in progress.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 20 February 1980:

quote.para: What action has the Government taken on each of the nine recommendations made by Major-General Stretton in his Report on the Darwin disaster of 1 974.

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The recommendations in the Report by Major-General Stretton which I tabled in the House on 1 December 1976 ranged widely; and I informed the House then that all these matters had been examined. Action on the recommendations involved not only the Department of Defence and many other Commonwealth Departments, but also State Departments and Agencies and non-government organisations as well.
Actions taken by my Department on Major-General Stretton's recommendations can be summarised as follows:
Recommendation (a)

All relevant Australian Government agencies should study the design of their communications system to ensure that before, during and after natural disasters, communications are efficient and guaranteed.'
Action:Steps have been taken to reduce the possibility of communications failure in future. These steps include improvements in the design of communications building and emergency equipment.
Recommendation (b)

Emergency broadcasting stations at Darwin and Sydney, originally built for Civil Defence purposes should, if practicable, be adapted to also cover emergencies arising from natural disasters. Some priority should be given to the construction of the Emergency Broadcasting Service in the Brisbane area and further consideration given to the construction of additional Emergency Broadcasting Stations in disaster-prone areas'.

Action:An inter-departmental committee on emergency broadcasting, chaired by the Director-General of the Natural Disasters Organisation (NDO), assesses possible requirements for such services, for civil defence or dealing with natural disasters. As a result of recommendations of this committee, the Postal and Telecommunications Department and Telecom are establishing a transportable emergency broadcasting station.

The committee has recommended against establishing an emergency broadcasting station in Brisbane, mainly for technical reasons and because adequate coverage is available from existing stations in the area.
Recommendations (c) and (d)

In the framing of the Natural Disasters Act, consideration should be given to providing for the modification of normal administrative procedures during periods of emergencies arising from natural disasters. The question of legal powers for a duly appointed Controller of the disaster site in an Australian Territory should also be considered.

There should be appropriate legal provisions requiring consultation with the Natural Disasters Organisation for the preparation of counter-disaster plans in Australian Territories. This matter should be considered in the framing of the Natural Disasters Act.'

Action:Legislation is not considered necessary to enable NDO to perform its essential functions. The Northern Territory and several States have counter-disaster legislation. The Australian Capital Territory does not have specific legislation, but a wide range of emergency powers are available.
Recommendation (e)
Negotiations should be undertaken with the States with a view to establishing a Natural Disasters Procedures Committee to meet under the Chairmanship of the Director-General NDO.'

Action:The Director-General of NDO meets regularly with the Directors of State and Territory emergency services, to discuss procedures and other matters relating to civil defence and natural disasters. Problems would be discussed in this forum.
Recommendation (f)
A Natural Disasters Voluntary Organisation Committee be formed under the chairmanship of the Director-General NDO.'

Action:A meeting was arranged by the Director-General of NDO of representatives of non-government organisations, to discuss the types of services they might provide in dealing with natural disasters, and how these services might be provided. It is considered that there is no need at this stage for establishing a national committee to co-ordinate voluntary assistance in natural disasters.
Recommendation (g) "The NDO be authorised to hold a central stock of key disaster relief stores which would be costed against the NDO division of the Defence Vote.'
Action:NDO has established, at the RAAF Base, Dubbo, a stock of equipment and other supplies for disaster relief.
Recommendation (h)

The Department of Education be requested to take immediate action to introduce the teaching of first aid into Australian Government secondary schools and to encourage the States to take similar action.'

Action:As a result of an approach by NDO, the Department of Education supported the teaching of first aid on a voluntary basis for the community generally, but it did not favour making the subject compulsory in schools.
Recommendation (i)
This recommendation comprised a list of actions by NDO which the Minister was asked to note.
Action:The Minister has noted the actions to which Major-General Stretton recommended his attention be drawn.

The honourable member can be assured that NDO continues to work closely with other Commonwealth departments, State and Territory counter-disaster organisations, and other authorities towards providing an effective system in Australia for coping with natural disasters.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Defence Forces: Postal Rate Concession (Question No. 6215)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 22 May 1 980:

item.para: Was the postal rate concession for mail posted to members of the Australian Defence Forces serving outside Australia abolished; if so, (a) when was it abolished, (b) why was it abolished and (c) what was the annual cost when it was abolished.
Are there any plans to re-introduce the concession; if so, what is the estimated annual cost of its reintroduction.

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

item.para: Yes.

item.label: (a)
item.para: 1 November 1978;

item.label: (b)
item.para: The concessions were originally introduced as an aid in maintaining morale during war situations. The Government, in 1978, reviewed the need for concessional rates of postage on mail matter posted to and by members of the Australian Defence Force serving in Malaysia, Singapore, Ismailia and on-board the RAN Ship attached under the Five Power Defence Arrangement. The majority of these concessions was applicable to members serving in Special Overseas Service Areas. As there were then no areas designated as Special Overseas Service Areas, the Government decided to abolish all postal concessions on mail matter posted to and by members of the Australian Defence Force serving overseas.

item.label: (c)
item.para: $242,000 for financial year 1 977-78.

On15 August 1980, I announced that letters to and from Naval personnel serving in Royal Australian Navy ships outside Australian waters would be carried by air at the Australian internal rate of postage. This would not apply to parcels. The introduction of this arrangement is not a restoration of the earlier forms of postal concessions. Rather, it recognises the problem of air mail delivery to and from ships deployed overseas, as distinct from mail for other Defence Force members in permanent locations overseas who receive allowances to compensate for higher postal costs. The additional annual cost of the new arrangements is expected to be approximately $28,000 at 1 979 prices.

subdebateinfo.title: Support Facilities at Edinburgh, South Australia (Question No. 6252)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 August 1980:

item.para: Has his attention been drawn to reports of suggested increased expenditure to upgrade support facilities at Edinburgh, South Australia, for air surveillance activities; if so, is there any substance in the reports.

Does the proximity of the Western Australian coast to points of interest in the Indian Ocean render a Western Australian air base a more satisfactory location for these activities.

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

item.para: Works, providing in part for the home-basing of the RAAF's maritime force at Edinburgh, were approved by Parliament in 1977, and are essentially complete. Further projects foreseen for Edinburgh over the next five years are of a normal upgrading nature applicable to all RAAF facilities.

Improvements to the maritime surveillance capability from RAAF Base Pearce are now well advanced. Improvements are also planned for the RAAF Learmonth airfield. These works are scheduled to begin in May 1981 subject to Parliamentary procedures.

Pearce and Learmonth in particular play an important role as staging bases for maritime reconnaissance flights into the Indian Ocean. Other considerations must be taken into account, however, in the siting of the main base for the RAAF's Long Range Maritime Patrol aircraft.

subdebateinfo.title: Banks: Disclosure to Taxation Office of Interest Payments (Question No. 6455)

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 27 August 1980:

item.para: Do arrangements exist between the Australian Taxation Office and savings or trading banks whereby details of interest payments on savings accounts or moneys put on deposit are made available for taxation assessment.

Are the banks required to make routinely available to the Taxation Office all details of all interest payments to depositors, irrespective of the sums involved or does the Office make specific requests from the banks concerning the accounts of individual depositors.

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: Arrangements exist for this kind of information to be supplied by banks. The income tax regulations require banks (and other companies) to furnish statements showing 'the names and addresses of all persons to whom interest in excess of one hundred dollars was paid or credited during the year preceding the year of tax, and the amount so paid or credited to each person'. The regulations also authorise the Commissioner of Taxation to make modifications of the particulars to be shown on the statements. These regulations are utilised in the administration of the taxation law but specific requests regarding individual depositors are also made as the occasion demands.
